Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 01:12PM VBG wrote: Hi Gwen, I am with you in your frustration over a recurrence when you did everything "right" the first time!  I was diagnosed with a 2nd bc 18 months after the first dx.  I had a lumpectomy, rads and tamox.......still 18 months later it was back.  As Shirlann points out the goods news is it is not a met but a second dx in the same breast. You should definitely get a second or third opinion especially when it comes to your surgery and recon.  I moved my treatment to a major cancer center after my second dx and am very happy that I am now at a more "cutting edge" hospital with all the latest treatment options and tests.    I have now had a bi lat, recon and did my first chemo treatment 2 weeks ago.  I also had my ovaries removed so I can start AIs when chemo is done. This whole thing sucks!  Not sure why some of us are able to deal with this once and beat it and some of us need to keep fighting.  All I know is that I will continue to fight like hell to stay with my DH and kids ages 9 and 11!  Hang in there Gwen you can beat this thing and so can I! Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2008 12:23PM VBG wrote: Cheri, I would also suggest have another radiologist look at your MRI.  Reading breast MRIs is challenging and not all radiologist have the experience to interpret them. As an FYI if your breast tissue is dense, which mine is too, it actually puts you at a significantly greater risk of BC.  That does not mean that you will ever get BC but is does mean you need to be very proactive and ask for/demand annual diagnostic tests which would be mammo and ultra sound.  Many top radiologist are now looking at MRI as the best screening tool for younger women with very dense tissue. My first cancer was only visible with ultrasound and my second was only visible on MRI.  I was 46 at inital dx and have very dense tissue.  Most likely you will be fine( and your husband will be right!) but it is always better to be sure!  Wishing you the best...... Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 09:36AM VBG wrote: Hi Donna, A Diagnostic Mammo is when your Dr orders a mammo and ultra sound at the same time.  Here at my facility it means the radiologist would be in site to oversee and check the ultra sound and mammo,.  A digital mammo is one that is done with a newer machine that uses a computer image and it is a better "picture" of higher quality than the older mammo machines.  My hospital here in Northern CA is just got their first digital machine.   A digital mammo is better for younger women and those with dense tissue as it is a higher resolution. You need to insure that you are proactive and push for additional tests, like an MRI, if you still have any concerns after your test tomorrow.  I had a number of "scares" and re screens which all turned out to be b9.  I am hopeful that yours too will be nothing.  You are better off then I was because you are using these boards to educate yourself! Wishing you good luck! Valerie

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 01:30AM VBG wrote: Hi All, I would strongly suggest that if you have microcalcifications that you push your doc for a diagnostic mammo every year.  This means that you would have a mammo and ultrasound.  The younger you are the more difficult it may be the get a good "read" with mammos alone.  Mammos are not the most effective tool for yournger women and women with dense breast tissue.  If you can get a digital mammo that is the better option for mammo alone. In my case my first BC was not visible on mammo( ultra sound screening found it) and my second was only visible on MRI.   I had dense breast tissue ( a risk factor), cycts and microcalcifications.  It is unfortunate that we have to manage our own healthcare.  I can tell you if I had not pushed for an MRI screening in conjunction with my follow up mammos/ultra sounds I would still not know that I had BC again.  My docs did not suggest it even though I was an obvious candidate for this type of screening!  While a BC diagnosis is something every woman fears it something you want to find at its earliest possible stage which is why screenings are so important.  Do whatever it takes to insure you are confident you are all clear!!! Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 09:22PM VBG wrote: Hi Pandora, I too had very "lumpy" breast, in fact after my breat MRI the radiologist's report said innumerable cysts!  I too was always worried about the cysts but the cysts themselves are actually no considered a risk factor.   I developed a great many more cysts in my 40s.  I also have "dense" breast tissue which is a very significant risk factor.  My biggest recommendation to you is to insure you are getting the best possible screening each year.  Be sure to get an ultrasound with your mammo and if you are able to get your Dr to sign off ask for a breat MRI since you would be considered high risk due to your family history.  Perhaps a clinical trial is available in your area for breast imaging?  The best situation is always to be in front of cancer and find it early.  I did and my prognosis is good.  I was vigilant in getting screenings and requesting tests.  Do contact your local hospital and see if they have a women's health center or breast cancer resource center to help with questions or concerns! Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 06:01PM VBG wrote: Hi Worriedhusband, I was diagnosed with stage 1 grade 1 invasive lobular/ductal.  I did not do a oncotype score that my initial dx and I did not do chemo.  I had a lumpectomy, radiation and tamoxifen.  I was 46 and with the same statistics you reference above I did not do chemo.  18 months later I had a recurrence of the same type of cancer in the same breast.  They believe it was an "off shoot" of my original cancer.  I had clear margins but with invasive bc there can be multifocal points.  I should have been the "poster girl" for lumpectomy/rads/tamox and this should have been successful for me but it was not.  On my second dx we did an oncotype and the score was 24.  Knowing what I know now I might have opted for a more aggressive surgery to insure that all the cancer was truly gone.  MRI/Mammos/ultrasound do not pick up everything.  Invasive cancers can be challenging because they can be hard to "see".  I also had microcalcifications, dense breast tissue,  and an invasive cancer all of which increased my risk factors. I am now doing chemo, even though my second dx was still stage 1 grade 1 and no nodes.  I would not think that your wife needs chemo but she needs to be hyper vigilant about pushing to insure that she gets the best possible screening to insure that the cancer stays gone.  So at the end of the day we all make choices/decisions and hope they are the right ones.  With cancer nothing is for sure but by educating yourself and "Pushing" your docs for information/tests/screening we stand a much better chance of a healthy outcome!  You are off to a great start by using these boards and asking great questions.  I wish  you the best, Valerie

Given your history and your dense breast tissue (which is a significant risk factor in itself) I would push for more info.  Since the radiologist does not "think" it is cancer it does not sound like he is sure what it is! Never be afraid to push for answers, ask lot of questions and follow your own instincts! I wish you the best! Valerie

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 11:45AM VBG wrote: Hi Teresa, My only risk factors were my paternal grandmother with BC at 42 and my dad/uncle with other cancers.  I too had genetic testing, twice, and was negative. I decided on a bi lat after my second dx of cancer.  So my story is that while my margins were "clear" there was most likely an off shoot of the original tumor that was not seen as it was too small.  Since this residual tumor did not respond to radiation or tamoxifen my choice seemed clear.  My docs did not disagree with my choice given my age. I also opted to have my ovaries removed since I will now need to be in AIs which are for post menopausal women.  At the time I was not expecting to do chemo which wold have knocked out my ovaries but I think I still would have opted to have them removed just to be sure. I do wish I had opted for a mastectomy after my initial dx.  If I had understood the nature of invasive cancers and my other risk factors this would have been my choice. I  wish I had know how radiation would complicate future surgeries if the bc came back and especially if I needed a mast.  I also wish I had gone for a second opinion at a major hospital after my initial dx. I did a lot of research after  my second dx and moved my care to UCSF.  I opted for a complete skin sparing surgery with expanders and will eventually have implants ( was not a good candidate for flaps). I made the choice for more aggressive surgery because I did not want the stress of waiting for results every 6 months.  My family is more important to me than breasts, ovaries or hair and I was determined to be more aggressive so that I beat this thing once and for all! Since you are triple neg your options are more limited as hormonal therapies are not a treatment option.   I am doing chemo now because my docs were concerned that my initial hormonal therapy, tamox, did not work for me so they are concerned that using AIs as our only weapon may not be enough. There are no right answers, we all just make the best decisions we can based on the information we have.  I would strongly suggest going for a second opinion just to confirm that another set of docs agrees with your treatment plan, pathology findings, etc.  If you do pursue further surgery be sure you find the best surgeon possible and again get a couple of opinions on surgery and recon if you choose that option.  I am glad I did! Wishing you the best, Valerie
